mmc1 mmc1.docx docx 26939888 APPLICATION APCATA 120435 120435 S0926-860X(25)00336-9 10.1016/j.apcata.2025.120435 The Authors Fig. 1 Raman spectra of the WT and VWT samples in the wavenumber range from 700 to 1200 cm−1; the spectra were collected under ambient conditions. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 DRUV-Vis spectra of the VWT catalysts recorded under ambient conditions. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 HCHO, NOx and NH3 conversion as well as formation of N2O, HCN and HCOOH during the combined HCHO/SCR reaction using the monolithic WT and VWT catalysts. Reaction conditions: y0(HCHO) = 100 ppm, y0(NOx) = 300 ppm (y0(NO2) < 2 ppm), y0(NH3) = 315 ppm, y0(CO) = 700 ppm, y0(CH4) = 1500 ppm, y0(O2) = 7 %, y0(CO2) = 12 %, y0(H2O) = 12 %, N2 balance, GHSV = 15,000 h−1. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Product formation (left) and conversion of HCHO, NOx and NH3 (right) during the combined HCHO/SCR reaction in the absence of CO2, CO and CH4 using the monolithic VWT_2.0 catalyst. Conditions: y0(HCHO) = 100 ppm, y0(NOx) = 300 ppm (y0(NO2) < 2 ppm), y0(NH3) = 315 ppm, y0(O2) = 7 %, y0(H2O) = 12 %, N2 balance, GHSV = 15,000 h−1. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Axial profiles of HCHO, NOx and NH3 conversion (left) as well as HCN and HCOOH formation (right) during the combined HCHO/SCR reaction along the monolithic VWT_2.0 catalyst at 500°C. Reaction conditions: y0(HCHO) = 100 ppm, y0(NOx) = 300 ppm (y0(NO2) < 2 ppm), y0(NH3) = 315 ppm, y0(CO) = 700 ppm, y0(CH4) = 1500 ppm, y0(O2) = 7 %, y0(CO2) = 12 %, y0(H2O) = 12 %, N2 balance, GHSV = 12,500 h−1 (L = 120 %) – 75,000 h−1 (L = 20 %). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Axial profiles of HCHO, NOx and NH3 conversion (left) as well as HCN and HCOOH formation (right) during the combined HCHO/SCR reaction along the monolithic VWT_2.0 catalyst at 250°C. Reaction conditions: y0(HCHO) = 100 ppm, y0(NOx) = 300 ppm (y0(NO2) < 2 ppm), y0(NH3) = 315 ppm, y0(CO) = 700 ppm, y0(CH4) = 1500 ppm, y0(O2) = 7 %, y0(CO2) = 12 %, y0(H2O) = 12 %, N2 balance, GHSV = 12,500 h−1 (L = 120 %) – 75,000 h−1 (L = 20 %). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Axial profiles of HCHO, NOx and NH3 conversion (left) as well as HCN and HCOOH formation (right) during the combined HCHO/SCR reaction along the monolithic VWT_2.0 catalyst at 200°C. Reaction conditions: y0(HCHO) = 100 ppm, y0(NOx) = 300 ppm (y0(NO2) < 2 ppm), y0(NH3) = 315 ppm, y0(CO) = 700 ppm, y0(CH4) = 1500 ppm, y0(O2) = 7 %, y0(CO2) = 12 %, y0(H2O) = 12 %, GHSV = 12,500 h−1 (L = 120 %) – 75,000 h−1 (L = 20 %). Table 1 Sample w(V 2 O 5 ) / wt% N s (V) / atoms/nm 2 E 0 / eV VWT_3.0 3.08 3.3 2.17 VWT_2.0 2.05 2.5 2.28 VWT_1.7 1.65 2.0 2.42 VWT_0.5 0.53 0.6 2.56 a Total vanadia content confirmed by ICP-OES b Ns(V) estimated from the V2O5 load, mass of monolith and BET surface area c E0 deduced from DRUV/Vis and Tauc equation Simultaneous HCHO and SCR conversion in lean-burn gas engine exhaust using V2O5/WO3-TiO2 catalysts Eleonore Siebecke Writing – original draft Project administration Methodology Investigation Christoph Hahn Writing – review & editing Visualization Validation Methodology Investigation Alexander Groß Writing – original draft Investigation Sven Kureti Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Validation Supervision Resources Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Technical University of Freiberg, Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering, Chair of Reaction Engineering, Fuchsmuehlenweg 9D, Freiberg 09596, Germany Technical University of Freiberg, Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering, Chair of Reaction Engineering Fuchsmuehlenweg 9D Freiberg 09596 Germany Technical University of Freiberg, Institute of Energy Process Engineering and Chemical Engineering, Chair of Reaction Engineering, Fuchsmuehlenweg 9D, 09596 Freiberg, Germany ⁎ Corresponding author. Monolithic V2O5/WO3-TiO2 catalysts with vanadia loads between 0 and 3 wt% were investigated toward the simultaneous HCHO oxidation and SCR reaction in synthetic lean-burn CH4 engine exhaust. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, temperature programmed desorption of NH3, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, UV/Vis spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy. The catalytic studies showed increasing NOx and HCHO conversions with rising V2O5 content accompanied by side-production of HCN. At 250°C and above the HCN formation mainly occurred at the catalyst inlet followed by hydrolysis and oxidation of HCN along the monolith. Moreover, the correlation of the characteristics with the performance of the catalysts suggested that highly dispersed VOx sites are predominately involved in the HCHO oxidation and HCN formation, whereas aggregated two-dimensional VOx species are less active. Finally, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopic studies suggested that formamide acts as key intermediate of the HCN formation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Gas engine exhaust V2O5/WO3-TiO2 Selective catalytic reduction Formaldehyde Hydrogen cyanide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The emission of the greenhouse gas (GHG) carbon dioxide (CO2) is increasingly becoming the focus of political, economic and scientific discourse due to the awareness on the global climate change. Lean-burn gas engines can provide a relevant contribution for the GHG reduction related to the high calorific value of CH4 (55.5 MJ/kg, diesel: 44.8 MJ/kg) [1]. Moreover, the sustainability of gas engines is drastically enhanced when fossil methane is substituted with biomethane. Nevertheless, the combustion of CH4 does not only lead to CO2 and water (H2O), but also results in the output of air pollutants such as nitrogen oxides (NOx), carbon monoxide (CO) and unburnt CH4. The CH4 slip (up to 3000 ppm [1]) is of special relevance, since methane has a much higher global warming potential than CO2. Options for the reduction of the methane output include internal engine measures, thermal post-combustion and catalytic oxidation. However, the catalytic oxidation of methane is still facing challenges regarding the long-term stability of the precious metal catalysts [2]. Additionally, a substantial disadvantage of gas engines is the emission of formaldehyde (HCHO) due to incomplete combustion of the fuel [1,3,4]. Formaldehyde is classified as a carcinogenic substance and therefore its emission is strictly regulated [5]. In the case of stationary gas engines, there was recently a particular focus on lowering HCHO and NOx emissions limits. For instance, the medium combustion plant directive of the European Union now demands the reduction of the NOx output from 500 mg/m³ to 100 mg/m³ : Additionally, for new combustion plants using natural gas a HCHO emission limit of 20 mg/m³ was introduced. This tightening makes a catalytic exhaust gas aftertreatment mandatory for most of the stationary gas engines operating under lean-burn conditions. The SCR procedure (Selective Catalytic Reduction) is widely used for the NOx removal from lean exhaust gases and was developed in the 1970s for waste incineration plants. Nowadays the SCR technology is also applied for lean-burn gas engines as well as diesel engines including stationary and mobile applications such as automobiles and ships [6,7]. SCR implies the conversion of NOx and ammonia (NH3) into N2 and H2O (4 NO + 4 NH3 + O2 → 4 N2 + 6 H2O). Due to the difficulties of NH3 storage, handling and transportation, an aqueous solution of urea is commonly used as NH3 source. V2O5/WO3-TiO2 (VWT) catalysts are widely used in stationary applications, where anatase-type TiO2 acts as support, WO3 as promoter and V2O5 as catalytically active component [8–11]. The optimal operation range of the VWT catalysts lies between 300 and 450°C and depends on the vanadium content. Higher vanadium contents decrease the activation energy, but also enhance the competing oxidation of NH3 to N2 or NO above 450°C. Thus, commercial VWT catalysts often contain a V2O5 content of about 2 wt%, which is also beneficial for the hydrothermal stability [12]. Moreover, for mobile applications, Fe or Cu containing zeolites, e.g. MFI, BEA and CHA, are used as SCR catalysts related to their enhanced activity at low temperatures (approx. 200 – 300°C) [13]. Furthermore, it has recently been reported that current SCR catalysts such as VWT, Fe-MFI and CHA zeolites are also active for the HCHO oxidation and therefore the simultaneous HCHO and SCR conversion has been suggested to remove both pollutants from the exhaust gas of lean gas engines [14–17]. A beneficial feature of this approach is that it excludes the need of an additional HCHO oxidation catalyst containing cost-intensive precious metals, e.g. Pt, Pd, Au [18], or iron oxides [19] as active components. However, it has been shown that the combined SCR-HCHO conversion on the SCR catalysts leads to the by-production of hydrogen cyanide (HCN) [14–17]. Although HCN is not a legally limited exhaust gas component, it is considered critical due to its high toxicity. Different mechanistic studies [14–17,20,21] agree that HCHO and NH3 are involved in the HCN formation. For Fe-MFI zeolite [17] and VWT [22], it has been assumed that HCHO is oxidized to formic acid (HCOOH), which subsequently reacts with NH3 to formamide (HCONH2) and water. Formamide finally decomposes to yield HCN and H2O. An alternative mechanism suggested for VWT includes the direct reaction of HCHO and NH3 to methanolamine (H2N-CH2-OH) [16]. Subsequently, the formed methanolamine oxidatively dehydrates to formamide, which is further converted into HCN and H2O. Moreover, the conversion of methanolamine into methanimine (H2C=NH) followed by oxidation to HCN and H2O has also been discussed [16]. The present study systematically investigates the combined HCHO and SCR reaction using monolithic VWT extrudates with different V2O5 loads. The investigations were performed in model exhaust gas related to stationary lean-burn gas engines. The catalysts were physico-chemically characterized by N2 physisorption, temperature-programmed desorption of NH3, X-ray diffraction, laser Raman spectroscopy and diffuse reflectance UV-Vis spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy. From the results of the characterization and the catalytic studies structure-activity relations were derived. In particular, determining properties of the catalysts toward the HCHO conversion and HCN formation were elucidated, which are currently not known from the literature. Moreover, as another innovation of this work axial concentration profiles were taken to investigate the HCN output as possible interaction of formation and decomposition of HCN along the monolithic catalysts. Finally, the present article aims to contribute to the debate on the mechanism of the HCN formation using in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy. 2 Experimental 2.1 Physico-chemical characterization N2 physisorption was carried out on a TriStar II (Micromeritics). The N2 isotherm was recorded at 77 K. For calculation of the BET surface area, the adsorption data in the p/p0 range from 0.05 to 0.2 were used. Before taking the isotherm, a sample mass of around 500 mg was cut out of the respective monolith and was outgassed under vacuum at 350°C for 16 h to remove adsorbed contaminants such as H2O and CO2. Powder X-ray diffraction XRD was conducted at room temperature using a D8 Discover (Bruker-AXS) with Co-Kα radiation (35 kV/40 mA). Before the analysis, respective catalyst was ground with a pestle. The diffraction pattern was collected in the 2θ range from 20° to 80° with an increment of 0.06° and a holding time of 4 s per step. For the evaluation of the diffractograms, the Powder Diffraction Files database was used. For temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD), respective catalyst was ground and sieved to a size of 125 – 250 μm. A granule mass of 500 mg was introduced into the quartz glass tube reactor (inner diameter: 8 mm) as packed bed, fixed with quartz wool and pre-treated in N2 flow at 350°C for 60 min to remove adsorbed contaminants. Then, the temperature was reduced to 50°C and a gas mixture of 1000 ppm NH3 and N2 (balance) was supplied. After saturation, the sample was purged with bare N2 to remove gaseous and weakly adsorbed NH3. When an outlet NH3 fraction of 5 ppm was reached, the TPD was started by heating at a rate of 10 K/min. The temperature was controlled by a K-type thermocouple directly placed in front of the catalyst bed, while always keeping the total gas flow at 500 ml/min (STP). NH3 was continuously monitored by a non-dispersive infrared (NDIR) spectrometer (X-STREAM, Emerson). Laser Raman spectroscopy (LRS) was made on an InVia Raman microscope (Renishaw) with a Nd:YAG laser (532 nm, 100 mW), a grating with 1800 lines per mm and a CCD array detector. The laser power was adjusted to 10 % with an excitation time of 20 s. The spectra of the ground catalyst powders were collected under ambient conditions. Diffuse reflectance UV-Vis spectroscopy (DRUV-Vis) of the powdered samples was carried out on a Lambda 850 spectrometer (Perkin Elmer) equipped with a photomultiplier detector and Praying Mantis reflectance optics (Harrick Scientific). The spectra were taken under ambient conditions adjusting a spectral range from 200 to 800 nm, a gap width of 1 nm, an integration time of 0.2 s/step and a scan rate of 267 nm/min. The collected data were transformed using the Kubelka-Munk function F(R) = (1-R)2/2 R; R is the ratio of the reflectance of the respective VWT sample and the WT reference. Band gap energies (E0) were derived from the DRUV/Vis spectra based on the Tauc equation (h∙ν∙F(R))1/2 = A∙(hν − E0), where the exponent ½ refers to the indirect electron transitions of vanadia acting as a semiconductor. In the Tauc diagram, E0 was obtained from the intercept of the abscissa and the tangent adjusted at the inflection point [23]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an Escalab 250 Xi spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The analyses of the powdered samples were carried out in ultra-high vacuum (10−7 mbar) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation, a spot size of 900 µm, pass energy of 20 eV and dwell time of 50 ms. 100 (W 4 f) or 200 scans (V 2p3/2) were accumulated to a spectrum. For calibration, the C 1 s line of the sample was used as internal reference (binding energy, BE = 284.8 eV). Avantage software (Thermo Fisher Scientific) was taken for data acquisition and analysis. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) including elemental mapping was made on a Quanta FEG - Versa 3D (FEI) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDAX AMETEK-Octane Plus). For the analyses, respective sample was placed on an adhesive carbon pad, and a tungsten incandescent cathode was used as electron source adjusting an acceleration voltage of 20 kV. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) was performed while mapping the sample at a magnification of 20,000 (512 ×400 pixel, local resolution: 39 nm, dwell time: 100 µs). The Ti K β1, V K α1,2 and W Mβ lines were taken for elemental analysis. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed using an ARCOS-II (Spectro Analytical Instruments) coupled with an electrothermal vaporizer (ETV 4000c, Spectral Systems). A sample mass of around 3 mg was added to the graphite boat of the ETV and was then heated in the furnace up to approx. 2500°C. For complete evaporation and introduction of the vapor into the plasma unit, a mixture of Ar and CCl2F2 was fed. The emission line of V (309.311 nm) was analyzed by CCD detectors using a Rowland circle alignment. Calibration was made using V solutions with defined V concentrations obtained from dissolving 1–8 mg V2O5 in 5 % HNO3. Before the calibration measurements and ETV, respectively, the liquid fraction of the V solutions was evaporated in the boat. Matrix effects were checked by adding approx. 0.5 mg of WT sample to the V2O5 used for calibration. 2.2 Catalytic studies The catalytic investigations toward the combined SCR and HCHO conversion were conducted on a laboratory test bench using a synthetic lean-burn gas engine exhaust. NH3, NO, CO, CH4, O2, CO2 and N2 (Air Liquide) were individually dosed by mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst), while H2O was supply by an evaporation and mixing system (Bronkhorst). HCHO was adjusted by a saturator heated to 45°C and filled with an aqueous HCHO solution (30 % HCHO, Carl Roth). The flow rate of the carrier gas N2 through the saturator was controlled to achieve the targeted concentration of HCHO. Gas phase analysis was continuously performed by a hot measuring FTIR spectrometer (Multi-Gas 2030, R4 method, MKS Instruments) including the detection of NH3, NO2, NO, CO, CO2, CH4, HCHO, HCOOH, HCN, H2O and HNCO. O2 was measured with a lambda probe (LSU 4.9, Bosch). All pipelines of the test bench where heated to 120°C to avoid condensation of H2O. For the catalytic studies, an externally heated quartz glass tube reactor (inner diameter: 22 mm) was used, wherein the monolithic catalysts were surrounded by quartz wool to avoid bypassing. The temperature was controlled by two K-type thermocouples directly located in front of and behind the respective monolith. Temperature differences between inlet and outlet thermocouple were always below 5 K. Four monolithic VWT full extrudates with V2O5 contents from 0.5 to 3.0 wt% and a W fraction of approx. 5 wt% were used, while a bare WO3-TiO2 (WT) monolith was taken as a reference. The monoliths were cuboids with a cross-sectional area of about 2 cm× 2 cm, a length of 8.9 cm and a cell density of 64, 72 and 88 cpsi corresponding to 36 and 49 channels per monolith (Table S1). Despite the different cell densities, the catalytic results are considered meaningful, as the total mass of vanadium present in the samples (Table S1) increases with the V2O5 content from 24 mg (VWT_0.5) to 164 mg (VWT_3.0). The monoliths were from industrial catalyst manufacturers. The sample codes used throughout this paper refer to the mass of V2O5; for instance VWT_0.5 is the monolith with a V2O5 content of 0.5 wt%. According to the typical composition of stationary lean gas engine exhaust and standard SCR conditions, the synthetic exhaust consisted of 300 ppm NOx (NO2 < 2 ppm), 315 ppm NH3, 100 ppm HCHO, 700 ppm CO, 1500 ppm CH4, 7 % O2, 12 % CO2 and 12 % H2O using N2 as balance. The total gas flow (F) was 8.9 l/min (STP) corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of about 15,000 h−1. The temperature was varied between 250 and 550°C in 50 K steps. Catalytic data were collected in steady state. Moreover, axial concentration profiles were investigated for the most effective catalyst to elucidate possible intermediates and follow-up reactions along the monolith. For this purpose, the relative length of the monolith was varied between 20 %, 40 %, 60 %, 100 % and 120 % related to the standard length (100 %) of 8.9 cm. Furthermore, all monoliths were also investigated at a relative length of 40 %. HCN conversion studies were conducted with a crushed and sieved catalyst (250–500 μm) at a total gas flow of 1.5 l/min (STP). The HCN proportion of 110 ppm was adjusted employing a defined gas mixture with N2 (Air Liquide). GHSV as well as O2 and H2O proportions were kept the same as for the tests with the monoliths. The performance of the catalysts is expressed in terms of (i) conversion (Xi = 1 - yi,out/yi,in) with yi,out being outlet and yi,in being inlet fraction of respective educt, (ii) outlet fractions of products (yj,out) and product selectivity (Sj = yj,out/(yi,in- yi,out). 2.3 Diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopic studies Mechanistic studies were performed with the VWT_2 catalyst using in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). The DRIFTS studies were conducted on a FTIR spectrometer (Tensor 27, Bruker) equipped with MCT detector and Praying Mantis optics (Harrick). The flow-through DRIFTS cell (Harrick) contained KBr windows and was connected to a gas handling system. Gases were supplied by mass flow controllers (Bronkhorst) using pure N2, synthetic air as well as calibration gas mixtures of 1000 ppm NH3 in N2 and 100 ppm HCHO in N2 (Air Liquide). A higher HCHO fraction of 500 ppm was adjusted by a heated saturator flushed with an appropriate flow of N2. The saturator contained paraformaldehyde powder (Carl Roth, 13C-labelled from Sigma-Aldrich), which decomposed to yield gaseous HCHO. Simultaneous surface and gas phase analyses were carried out by feeding the effluents of the DRIFTS cell (Harrick) into a FTIR analyzer (Multi-Gas 2030, MKS Instruments). The DRIFT spectra were collected between 600 and 4000 cm−1 with a resolution of 1 cm−1, while the IR beam path was permanently flushed with N2 to maintain a stable background. 800 scans were accumulated to a background spectrum and 380 scans to a sample spectrum resulting in a time resolution of approx. 5 min. The spectra are presented using the -logR function, where the reflectance R is the intensity ratio of sample and background scans. Opus Software (Bruker) was taken to process the spectral data. Before the investigations, powdered catalyst (approx. 40 mg) was introduced into the DRIFTS cell and was pre-treated at 350 °C in N2 flow for 90 min. Then, the temperature was decreased to 250 °C in flowing N2 and a background spectrum was taken. Subsequently, a mixture of 50 ppm HCHO and N2 (balance) was dosed and spectra were continuously recorded. After approx. 65 min of HCHO exposure, a mixture of 50 ppm HCHO, 50 ppm NH3 and 7 % O2 (N2 balance) was supplied and spectra were continuously recorded again. The total gas flow was always kept at 200 ml/min (STP). Moreover, a further DRIFTS study was performed in a very similar way adjusting 500 ppm HCHO and NH3 each and 7 % O2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physical-chemical properties of the catalysts The XRD patterns of the VWT samples (Fig. S1) evidence that the support exists in the form of anatase-type TiO2 (PDF 00 021 1272), whereas no reflexes of crystalline V2O5 or WO3 domains are observed. The Raman spectra of the WT and VWT samples confirm the presence of the anatase-type TiO2; the corresponding spectra and peak assignments are given in Fig. S2 [24,25]. Additionally, weak peaks are observed at 792 cm−1 and 981 cm−1 ( Fig. 1). The former feature is assigned to the first overtone of the deformation vibration of TiO2 (B1 g) appearing at 395 cm−1 [25], whereas crystalline WO3 entities might also contribute [26,27]; although crystalline WO3 is not detected by XRD, Raman spectroscopy is generally more sensitive to detect minor components. Furthermore, the peak at approx. 981 cm−1, also observed for the bare WT reference, is mainly associated with ν(WO) vibrations of polymeric tungsten oxide species [27,28]. However, it is assumed that ν(VO) vibrations of dispersed vanadium oxide entities, expected at about 1025 cm−1 [24], also contribute to this rather broad feature. This supposition is tentatively supported by the shoulder at the high frequencies flank of the 981 cm−1 peak observed for the samples with the two highest vanadia loads of 2 and 3 wt%. By contrast, crystalline V2O5 species supposed at approx. 995 cm−1 [26,27,29,30] do not appear and are only expected at clearly higher V2O5 loads, which are above the monolayer coverage of approx. 5 wt% [24,31]. Moreover, the V surface concentration is estimated from the V2O5 loading, which was confirmed by ICP-OES ( Table 1), the mass and the BET surface area of the respective monolith. As a result, the V surface coverage increases from 0.6 to 3.3 atoms/nm2 as the vanadia content rises (Table 1). Following the literature [23,31], the V surface concentration of 0.6 atoms/nm2 present in the VWT_0.5 sample suggests predominate existence of monomeric or highly dispersed VOx moieties. By contrast, the samples with the higher V surface proportions of 2.0, 2.5 and 3.3 atoms/nm2 (1.7 – 3.0 wt% V2O5) additionally exhibit oligomeric and polymeric VOx species existing in the form of two-dimensional structures [23,31]; the aggregation degree of these VOx entities obviously increases with growing V2O5 content. However, the V surface amounts are far from that, which refer to crystalline vanadia (≥ 8 V atoms/nm2). The DRUV/Vis spectra of the VWT samples show a feature at around 398 nm, which clearly increases in intensity with rising vanadia content ( Fig. 2). The band is due to ligand to metal charge transfer processes (LMCT) within the VOx species referred to the transition of electrons from 2p orbitals of O2- to unoccupied 3d0 orbitals of the V5+ cations. The asymmetric shape on the low energy side at approx. 450 nm, which gets more pronounced with increasing V2O5 content, is associated with the aggregation of the vanadia species [32] related to the rising V surface proportion (Table 1). On the contrary, bands at approx. 650 nm and 830 nm, which might be assigned to reduced vanadium sites (V4+ and V3+), do not appear [33]. The band gap energies deduced from the DRUV/Vis spectra according to the Tauc equation show decreasing E0 values from 2.56 eV (VWT_0.5) to 2.17 eV (VWT_3) as the load of V2O5 rises (Table 1). This decrease in the band gap energies is interpreted with the increasing aggregation of the vanadia species in line with the growing V surface proportions. The E0 value of the VWT_3 sample (2.17 eV) showing the highest V surface amount and the strongest VOx aggregation degree among the samples is close to that of bulk vanadium oxide (2.09 – 2.2 eV) [23,34]. Moreover, VWT_0.5 reveals the highest E0 of 2.56 eV, which is typical for highly dispersed vanadia agreeing with the lowest V surface content of 0.6 atoms/nm2. Note that a higher V dispersion (0.1 atoms/nm2) shifts the band gap energy up to 3.0 eV [35]. The XP spectroscopic investigations showed a V 2p3/2 peak at around 516.3 (Fig. S3, left). V 2p3/2 BE values were reported from 515.9 to 516.5 eV for V4+ and from 516.8 to 517.9 eV for V5+ oxide species suggesting the co-existence of V4+ and V5+ oxide moieties on the surface of all VWT samples [36–39]. The presence of the V4+ species is related to reduction of V5+ in the ultra-high vacuum of the XP spectrometer as proven in the literature [40,41]. As expected, no V signal appeared in the XP spectrum of the bare WT support. Moreover, all samples showed a W 4 f7/2 peak at 35.7 eV (Fig. S3, right) assigned to surface W6+ oxide species [42,43]. It should be noted that the W 4 f5/2 feature was omitted for analysis due to superimposition by the Ti 3p peak of the TiO2 support at 37.5 eV. No indication for tungsten in lower oxidation states was observed due to missing peaks at lower BE, which are expected with shifts of 1–1.3 eV for W5+ and 2.6–2.8 eV for W4+ referred to W6+ [42,43]. Furthermore, the BET surface area of the VWT monoliths (Table S2) range from 54 to 60 m2/g, while that of the WT reference is slightly higher (65 m2/g). The surface-related NH3 uptake of the WT and VWT samples is very similar (2.8 – 3.0 μmol/m2, Table S2) suggesting that the NH3 adsorption predominately occurs on the WO3-TiO2 substrate in line with the sub-monolayer vanadia coverage discussed above. The SEM images (Fig. S4) show a rather dense surface microstructure of the samples, while the texture of bare WT and the catalysts with vandia loads of 0.5 and 1.7 wt% is coarser than that of the samples with the highest V2O5 contents. However, these microstructural differences do not clearly affect the specific surface area, which is very similar for all the samples (Table S2). The EDS mapping (Fig. S5) demonstrates that in all VWT catalysts tungsten as well as vanadium are homogenously distributed onto the TiO2 support. This is in line with the Raman spectroscopic and UV/Vis spectroscopic analyses suggesting that V and W species exist in two-dimensional surface structures without substantial presence of particulate moieties. 3.2 Simultaneous HCHO and SCR conversion on the WT and VWT monoliths The simultaneous HCHO and SCR conversion on the WT and VWT monoliths was investigated in a synthetic lean-burn gas engine exhaust containing 300 ppm NOx (< 2 ppm NO2), 100 ppm HCHO, 700 ppm CO, 1500 ppm CH4, 7 % O2, 12 % CO2 and 12 % H2O with a molar NH3/NOx ratio of 1.05. Fig. 3 shows that the HCHO conversion increases with temperature and V2O5 content, whereas the samples with 2.0 and 3.0 wt% V2O5 reveal similar performances. However, for the V2O5 loadings of 1.7 wt% and above, the HCHO conversion slightly decreases from 500°C to 550°C. This is associated with the starting oxidation of CH4, which reveals a conversion below 5 % at 550°C and leads to a minor formation of HCHO; note that in the absence of CH4 the HCHO conversion is not decreased at 550°C. The outlet CO gas fraction is for all catalysts above the inlet fraction in the entire temperature range, which leads to the assumption that CO is one of the HCHO conversion products in line with the literature [44]. Furthermore, the SCR efficiency of the catalysts follows a similar trend to the HCHO oxidation (Fig. 3), i.e. the NOx conversion increases with temperature and V2O5 content in line with the literature [7,12]. However, at the higher temperatures the SCR performance of the VWT catalysts decreases, while the decay is strongest for VWT_3. Although VWT-based SCR catalysts stand out due to their high selectivity toward N2, the NOx conversion is reduced above approx. 450°C by the competing NH3 oxidation yielding N2 (4 NH3 + 3 O2 → 2 N2 + 6 H2O) and NO (4 NH3 + 5 O2 → 4 NO + 6 H2O) [12,34–36]. Additionally, Fig. 3 shows that the NH3 oxidation also results in the production of N2O (4 NH3 + 4 O2 → 2 N2O + 6 H2O). The NH3 oxidation including the N2O formation is enhanced by the increase in the V2O5 content and the proportion of aggregated VOx species as deduced from the V surface contents and the band gap energies (Table 1) [12,45–51]. As a consequence of the NH3 oxidation, the conversion of NH3 exceeds that of NOx. Moreover, the simultaneous HCHO/SCR conversion also results in the formation of HCN (Fig. 3) as reported recently [14–17]. Interestingly, even the bare WT sample produces some HCN, which increases with rising temperature (14 ppm HCN at 550°C) [16]. Additionally, the HCN formation on the VWT_0.5 catalyst also grows with the temperature, whereas the HCN output is clearly higher compared to WT; for instance, the HCN fraction is 30 ppm at 550°C. These results evidence that the HCN production is substantially enhanced by the VOx species. Since the VOx sites of the VWT_0.5 catalyst predominately exist in the form of highly dispersed VOx entities (Section 3.1), it is deduced that these species are involved in the formation of HCN. In contrast to WT and VWT_0.5, the catalysts with the higher V2O5 loads show two HCN production regimes. A low-temperature HCN maximum appears at 250°C and 300°C, respectively, whereas with rising temperature the HCN formation drops at first, but again increases at 400°C and above. An exception is the catalyst with the highest V2O5 load (VWT_3.0), which again shows a decrease in the HCN output above 450°C. The HCN formation on the VWT_2 and VWT_3 catalysts, which reveal some proportions of oligomeric VOx species (Section 3.1), indicate that most probably the vanadia oligomers are also involved in the HCN formation. The role of the different VOx species in the HCHO conversion is discussed more in detail in Section 3.6. Following the literature [14–17] the HCN formation on the WT and VWT catalysts is due to the reaction of NH3 with HCHO and O2 (Eq. 1). Additionally, the relevance of Eq. 1 is checked by the NH3 balance (Eq. 2) taking into account the inlet NH3 fraction (y0(NH3)), the sum of the outlet fractions of NH3 (y(NH3)) and HCN (y(HCN)) and the amount of NH3 consumed in the SCR reaction (Δy(NH3)SCR = y0(NOx) – y(NOx)). As a result, the difference of inlet and outlet species is below 8 ppm for all catalysts between 250 and 350°C substantiating the significance of Eq. 1. At higher temperatures the starting NH3 oxidation makes this balance difficult, particularly for the highly loaded catalysts. (1) 2 NH3 + 2 HCHO+ O2 → 2 HCN + 4 H2O (2) y0(NH3) = y(NH3) + y(HCN) + Δy(NH3)SCR Moreover, it has to be stated that the literature shows different temperature dependencies of the HCN formation on VWT catalysts as summarized in Table S3 [14–17]. A pronounced HCN formation was observed between 250 and 450°C using a VWT powder catalyst at a GHSV of 70,000 h−1, whereupon the presence of H2O clearly decreased the HCN production [14,15]. However, it was reported that VWT-coated monoliths continuously increase the HCN output with rising temperature (200–500°C), which is likely due to the clearly shorter residence time on the catalytic coating (GHSV: 50,000 and 100,000 h−1 referred to the monolith volume) [16,17]. By contrast, the present investigations performed with monolithic VWT extrudates at a GHSV of 15,000 h−1 show a minimum of HCN production at around 400°C (Fig. 3). As will be shown in Sections 3.4 and 3.5, the temperature, H2O content and space velocity significantly affect the formation and decay of HCN resulting in specific emission profiles. Furthermore, some trace amounts of HCOOH (≤ 4 ppm) are detected on the VWT monoliths clearly decreasing with temperature (Fig. 3). 3.3 Detailed carbon mass balance of the HCHO/SCR reaction using the VWT monolith with a V2O5 load of 2 wt% To quantify the products of the HCHO conversion the combined HCHO/SCR reaction was investigated in the absence of CH4, CO and CO2. For this purpose, the VWT_2.0 catalyst was used due to its high deNOx and HCHO conversion efficiency (Fig. 3). Fig. 4 shows that the conversions of NOx, NH3 and HCHO and the yields of CO, CO2, HCOOH and HCN are very similar to the test performed with CH4, CO and CO2. An exception is the HCHO conversion, which increases above 500°C, supporting the above supposition that in the presence of methane a small amount of CH4 is catalytically oxidized to HCHO (CH4 + O2 → HCHO + H2O). Taking into account the detected products a mass balance of carbon is set up (Eq. 3), where y0(HCHO) is the inlet fraction of HCHO and y(i) the outlet fractions of HCHO, CO, CO2, HCOOH and HCN. The results are summarized in Table S4 showing a difference between the inlet and outlet species of 13 ppm and below. Hence, the mass of carbon is well balanced excluding any further carbon containing species of relevance. (3) y0(HCHO) = y(HCHO) + y(CO) + y(CO2) + y(HCOOH) + y(HCN) Additionally, the selectivities deduced from the outlet fractions (Table S5) evidence that HCN is the major product of the HCHO conversion at 200°C with a selectivity of approx. 40 %, whereas above this temperature CO is predominately formed reaching a maximal CO selectivity of about 90 % at 400°C. At 500 and 550°C the CO selectivity slightly decreases due to the growing production of HCN and CO2 each revealing a selectivity of 12 % at 550°C. CO is mainly formed from the oxidation of HCHO according to the overall Eq. 2 HCHO + O2 → 2 CO + 2 H2O [14,16]. However, the pathways of the CO formation cannot be thoroughly unravelled from this product analysis, for instance it remains unclear to which extent CO is produced from the thermal decomposition of HCOOH and from HCN hydrolysis (Section 3.4). Additionally, small amounts of CO2 form at 500 and 550°C (Fig. 4), probably due to the oxidation of CO, whereas water-gas shift reaction (CO + H2O ⮀ CO2 + H2) or direct oxidation of HCHO to CO2 (HCHO + O2 → CO2 + H2O) cannot be excluded completely. At 200°C and 250°C minor CO2 proportions are also produced. Following the literature [14] it may be speculated that this evolution of CO2 is related to the reaction of HCHO with NO2 or surface nitrites/nitrates originated from the adsorption of NOx. Moreover, the appearance of adamantane-related hexamethylenetetramine (C6H12N4), formed from the reaction of HCHO and NH3, has recently been reported when the HCHO/SCR conversion on a VWT catalyst is performed below 250°C and without H2O [14]. However, as already mentioned above, the mass of carbon is balanced within the accuracy of the FTIR analyzer and therefore it is assumed that no significant amount of this substance is produced under the conditions established in the present study. 3.4 Axial conversion and product profiles along the VWT monolith with a V2O5 load of 2 wt% Axial concentration profiles have been investigated to check possible intermediates and follow-up reactions along the VWT_2 monolith during the simultaneous HCHO/SCR reaction. The VWT_2 catalyst has been used due to its high HCHO conversion and SCR activity (Fig. 3). The investigations were performed at 200, 250 and 500°C, since these temperatures provide a prominent yield of HCN (Fig. 3). As described in Section 2.2, the axial concentration profiles have been taken by using different catalyst lengths (L = 20 – 120 %) corresponding to residence times (τ) between 288 ms (L = 120 %, GHSV = 12,500 h−1) und 48 ms (L = 20 %, GHSV = 75,000 h−1). The relative length of 100 % (τ = 240 ms, GHSV = 15,000 h−1) refers to the standard reaction conditions used in Sections 3.2 and 3.3. As expected, Figs. 5 – 7 show that for the three temperatures the conversions of NH3, HCHO and NOx rise with increasing catalyst length and longer residence time, respectively. At 500°C NH3 is completely consumed at the relative lengths of 100 % and 120 %, while HCHO almost reaches full conversion (Fig. 5, left). In contrast to that, the HCN proportion continuously declines with the catalyst length (Fig. 5, right). This suggests that HCN rapidly forms at the inlet of the catalyst - related to the high concentrations of NH3 and HCHO, and along the catalyst the formed HCN undergoes consecutive reactions, whereupon the decay is faster than the formation. No formic acid is detected, probably due to its rapid decomposition at 500°C [22,52]. At 200 and 250°C, the conversion levels of NOx, NH3 and HCHO are lower as compared to 500°C (Figs. 6 and 7) in line with the above investigations (Figs. 3 and 4). Contrary to 500°C, at 250°C the HCN proportion increases between 20 % and 40 % length, remains close to constant (about 15 ppm) when extending the length from 40 % to 100 % and slightly decreases to 12 ppm at the length of 120 % (Fig. 6, right). The increasing HCN proportions at the lengths of 20 and 40 % refer to the relatively high fractions of HCHO and NH3, which accelerate the formation of HCN, whereas at 250°C the decomposition of HCN is relatively slow compared to 500°C. However, for the greater length (L = 60 and 80 %) and increasing residence time, respectively, the HCN formation weakens, as the remaining proportions of HCHO and NH3 get smaller due to the proceeding conversion along the catalyst. Consequently, the rate of the HCN decay mechanism predominates leading to decreasing amounts of HCN at the lengths of 100 and 120 %. Moreover, very low HCOOH fractions of about 2 ppm appear along the monolith (Fig. 6, right). A different axial profile of HCN is observed at 200°C (Fig. 7, right), which shows continuous increase in HCN along the catalyst (max. 15 ppm), i.e. the HCN decomposition is not yet activated or the HCN formation rate is clearly higher than that of the decay. Additionally, significant amounts of HCOOH (max. 10 ppm) are detected following a very similar trend to HCN. 3.5 HCN conversion using the VWT monolith with a V2O5 load of 2 wt% To evaluate the follow-up reactions of HCN taking place along the VWT_2.0 monolith, the oxidation (Eq. 4) and hydrolysis of HCN (Eq. 5) are examined. In the literature it has been shown that TiO2 [22,52,53] strongly enhances the hydrolysis and oxidation of HCN above 200°C, whereas VWT is reported less active [52]. (4) 4 HCN + 5 O2 → 4 CO2 + 2 N2 + 2 H2O (5) HCN + H2O → NH3 + CO As described in Section 2.2, the HCN oxidation and hydrolysis studies were conducted with VWT_2.0 granules to reduce the flow of the highly toxic HCN. The GHSV was maintained at 15,000 h−1 as for the studies with the monoliths (Figs. 3 and 4). Note that the hydrolysis study has been carried out in the presence of O2 to avoid reduction of the VWT catalyst by both HCN as well as products evolved. It is also important to state that the activity and selectivity of the VWT_2.0 granules during the combined HCH/SCR conversion (Fig. S6) is very similar to that of the monolith (Fig. 3). The HCN oxidation study, performed in the presence of 7 O2 (without H2O), shows that the conversion of HCN starts at 350°C and continuously increases with temperature reaching complete conversion at 550°C ( Fig. 8, left). CO2 is observed as major product, whereas CO forms in minor amounts (Fig. 8, middle) suggesting that HCN is mainly oxidized to CO2 and N2 (Eq. 4). It has been reported that the catalytic HCN oxidation follows a two-step mechanism including the formation (HCN + 0.5 O2 → HNCO) and subsequent oxidation of isocyanic acid (2HNCO + 1.5 O2 → 2 CO2 + N2 + H2O) [22]; in the present experiment HNCO was not found, which might be due to its high reactivity. Moreover, the mass of carbon is well balanced based on the detected inlet fraction of HCN and the outlet fractions of HCN, CO and CO2 (Eq. 6) showing a difference of max. 1 ppm only. (6) y0(HCN) = y(HCN) + y(CO) + y(CO2) Additionally, small fractions of N2O and NOx (mainly NO) appear, probably produced as side products of the oxidation of HCN and HCNO, respectively. The N2O formation starts at 400°C and goes through a maximum of 20 ppm at 550°C, whereas the NOx formation begins at clearly higher temperature (500°C) and increases to 24 pm at 550°C. Additionally, it may be speculated that some NOx and N2O is formed from the oxidation of NH3 originating from the hydrolysis of HCN according to Eq. 5, whereupon the involved water is due to the HCN oxidation (Eq. 4). The investigation of the HCN hydrolysis, conducted in the additional presence of 12 % H2O, shows much faster reaction of HCN achieving complete conversion already at 350°C (Fig. 8, left). However, above 450°C the conversion slightly decreases in line with the literature [22]. Since such effect does not appear in the sole presence of O2, it is supposed that the declining HCN conversion is due to the decrease in the H2O coverage of the VWT_2.0 catalyst, which obviously decreases with rising temperature. The products in the presence of H2O shift to mainly CO and NH3 according to Eq. 5 (Fig. 8, right) indicating that the hydrolysis is preferred in the presence of H2O and O2. This pathway is substantiated by the very similar amounts of CO and NH3 evolved at 250°C (56 and 55 ppm) and 300°C (99 and 95 ppm). Moreover, the mass of carbon is balanced (Eq. 6) within a difference of max. 7 ppm between inlet and outlet fractions proving that no other carbon species are formed in substantial amounts. Based on the literature [20] it is assumed that the HCN hydrolysis leads to formamide (HCN + H2O → HCONH2), which is subsequently converted into ammonium formate (HCONH2 + H2O → NH4 + HCOO-). Then, ammonium formate likely decomposes to yield NH3 and formic acid (NH4 + HCOO- → NH3 + HCOOH). Finally, the later is dehydrated (HCOOH → H2O + CO). HCOOH was again not detected during the experiment associated with its fast decomposition and thermal instability, respectively. Moreover, at 350°C and above, the NH3 proportion clearly decreases despite the high conversion of HCN and the appearance of CO (Fig. 8, right). This effect is explained by the oxidation of the formed NH3 to N2 and NO, while the latter subsequently undergoes SCR reaction enhancing the consumption of NH3. Moreover, at 500 and 550°C, CO2 and NO are also detected. Since, the VWT_2.0 catalyst does not reveal an appreciable CO oxidation activity (Section 3.2), the formation of CO2 is ascribed to the HCN oxidation (Eq. 4), which interferes with the HCN hydrolysis at the higher temperatures. As mentioned above, the appearance of NO at 500 and 550°C is referred to the oxidation of NH3 and/or HCN. As a result of the HCN conversion experiments, the increasing HCN formation, observed along the VWT monolith at 200°C (Fig. 7), is referred to the continuous production of HCN, whereas the consecutive hydrolysis and oxidation is not yet activated. However, at 500°C, high conversion of HCN is achieved by the oxidation as well as hydrolysis both showing fast reaction rates at this temperature (Fig. 8, left). From this result it is inferred that the clear HCN decay along the monolith observed at 500°C (Fig. 5) is related to the hydrolysis and oxidation of the formed HCN (Eqs. 4 and 5). Additionally, at 500°C the oxidation of NH3 increases, which lowers the HCN formation rate along the VWT monolith. The axial profile of HCN at 250°C (Fig. 6) is explained by the relatively slow hydrolysis at this temperature. Thus, in the inlet part of the catalyst the HCN formation increases, whereas in the further course along the catalyst the HCN formation slows down, as NH3 is increasingly consumed by the SCR reaction. As a result, the rate of the HCN hydrolysis is slightly faster than that of the HCN formation leading to the decreased HCN proportion along the monolith. 3.6 Effect of content and nature of VOx species on the HCHO oxidation during the simultaneous HCHO/SCR conversion From the V surface proportions (Ns(V)) and the VOx band gap energies (E0; Table 1) it has been concluded (Section 3.1) that the sample with the lowest V2O5 load (0.5 wt%) mainly reveals monomeric and highly dispersed VOx species, respectively, while the catalysts with the higher V2O5 contents (1.7, 2.0 and 3.0 wt%) additionally exhibit oligomeric and possibly polymeric VOx entities. Obviously, the aggregation degree of oligomeric and polymeric VOx species increases with rising vanadia load. For the evaluation of the activity and selectivity of the VOx species during the HCHO conversion the simultaneous HCHO/SCR reaction was investigated using all monolithic catalysts with a relative length of 40 % (GHSV: 37,500 h−1) to suppress the consecutive HCN decay. In these additional tests, a HCHO proportion of 200 ppm was taken and, as done in Section 3.3, CH4, CO and CO2 were not dosed to accurately specify the product selectivity. The HCHO/SCR studies were carried out at 250 and 300°C, while at 200°C the HCHO conversion on the catalysts with the lower V2O5 loads was too small (≤ 12 %) to provide meaningful selectivity data. Fig. 9 (left) shows higher HCHO conversions at 300°C (up to 58 %) than at 250°C (up to 45 %), while at both temperatures the conversion increases with rising V2O5 content. Interestingly, even the bare WT catalyst shows some HCHO conversion (approx. 14 %), which, however, is clearly lower than that of the VWT samples. To assess the specific efficiency of the vanadium sites the turnover frequency (TOF) of HCHO per V atom is used. The turnover frequency is defined as TOF = ṅ(ΔHCHO) / n(V). ṅ(ΔHCHO) is the molar HCHO conversion rate on the respective VWT catalyst reduced by the that of the bare WT sample, i.e. ṅ(ΔHCHO) = (ṅ(HCHO)in - ṅ(HCHO)VWT,out) - (ṅ(HCHO)in - ṅ(HCHO)WT,out), while n(V) is the total molar amount of vanadium present in respective catalyst (Table S1). As a result, the sample with the lowest V2O5 load (0.5 wt%), which exclusively reveals highly dispersed VOx species, demonstrates the highest TOF among the catalysts (Fig. 9, right). The TOF tends to decrease with rising V2O5 content suggesting that the oligomeric and polymeric VOx entities are less active in the HCHO oxidation than the highly dispersed VOx sites. It should be mentioned that the TOF values of the samples VWT_1.7 and VWT_2.0 resemble, probably due to similar V surface concentrations (Ns(V): 2.0 and 2.5 atoms/nm2) and VOx structures (E0: 2.42 and 2.28 eV). The high specific oxidation activity of the highly dispersed sites is in line with the literature showing that the efficiency of highly aggregated and crystalline vanadia entities in the oxidation of HCHO to HCOOH is minor compared to smaller VOx moieties [54]. Recently, it has been shown that the oxidation of HCHO to HCOOH on VOx species most likely follows an associative mechanism including reactive surface peroxide as key intermediate [55,56]. In contradiction to the present findings, it has been suggested that polymeric VOx entities are more easily reduced during the oxidation of butane, butene and methanol thus revealing higher oxidation performance compared to highly dispersed sites [57]. Additionally, it was recently shown that the oxidation activity of VWT is enhanced compared to VOx/TiO2. It is assumed that the interaction of the vanadia sites with the tungsten oxide component results in a faster oxidation of the formates and reoxidation of the VOx entities [15]. Moreover, Fig. 10 evidences that at 250 and 300°C the oxidation of HCHO mainly leads to the formation of CO (HCHO + 0.5 O2 → CO + H2O), whereupon the WT sample reveals the highest CO selectivity (79 % at 250°C, 77 % at 300°C). All VWT catalysts provide a similar CO selectivity ranging from 56 % to 67 % at 250°C and from 69 % to 77 % at 300°C. It may be supposed that the decomposition of HCOOH observed as a minor by-product of the HCHO oxidation probably contributes to the CO formation (HCOOH → CO + H2O). Following this assumption, the lower CO selectivity of the VWT catalysts compared to WT might be explained by the reaction of HCOOH with NH3 to form formamide (HCOOH + NH3 → HCONH2), which subsequently decomposes to HCN and H2O (HCONH2 → HCN + H2O). The selectivity of HCN on the VWT catalysts lies between 20 % and 30 % irrespective of the temperature and the V2O5 content, while WT only shows a minor HCN selectivity of approx. 5 %. The frequency of the HCN formation per V atom (Fig. S7) calculated according to the TOF shows highest frequency for the VWT_0.5 sample, while the remaining VWT catalysts reveal rather similar HCN production frequencies. These findings show that the highly dispersed VOx sites also enhance the HCN formation as referred to the aggregated VOx species. This superiority might be a consequence of the higher HCOOH formation activity of the highly dispersed VOx entities as discussed above [54]. Furthermore, at 250°C the CO2 selectivity decreases from 17 % to 1 % with rising vanadia load, while the HCOOH selectivity is minor for all samples (5–7 %). Additionally, only small CO2 (0–6 %) and HCOOH selectivities (0–1 %) appear at 300°C. In line with the HCN conversion studies (Fig. 8) these minor CO2 selectivities substantiate that the HCN oxidation (Eq. 4) is not the dominating pathway during the HCN decay at 250 and 300°C. 3.7 Mechanism of the HCHO/SCR conversion The surface reactions occurring during the HCHO/SCR conversion on the VWT_2 catalyst were investigated by in-situ DRIFT spectroscopy. The studies were performed at 250°C using very low fractions of HCHO (≤ 100 ppm) and NH3 (50 ppm) to reduce the superimposition of bands in the range from 1200 to 1800 cm. Pre-adsorption of HCHO (100 ppm) shows that all the detected DRIFTS bands continuously grow within 30 min and remain stable afterward. The adsorption of HCHO ( Fig. 11) results in the formation of surface formate species related to the very broad feature at around 1560 cm−1 (νas(OCO)) and the less intense band at 1395 cm−1 (νs(OCO)) [58,59]. These bands are accompanied by the signal of the corresponding ν(CH) vibrations at 2840 cm−1 and four bands between 2855 and 2970 cm−1 referred to νas(OCO)+ ν(CH) vibrations of the formate species. This multitude of bands between 2855 and 2970 cm−1 as well as the broadening of the 1560 cm−1 band suggest that the surface formates exist in different coordination modes (bidentate, bridged) and are probably bound to different adsorption sites, i.e. V5+, W6+ or Ti4+. By contrast, oligomeric (1405 cm−1 (δ(CH2), 2940 cm−1 (νCH2)) and polymeric [CH2O]n species (1470 cm−1 (δ(CH2), 2921 cm−1 (ν(CH2)) as well as dioxymethylene entities (1473 (δ(CH2), 2882 cm−1 (ν(CH2)) were not identified [19,58]. The weak band at 1340 cm−1 with a shoulder at 1355 cm−1 is tentatively ascribed to carbonate species (νs(CO) formed from the chemisorption of CO [60]. The appearance of CO is proven by FTIR gas phase analysis of the DRIFTS cell effluents ( Fig. 12) and is related to the HCHO oxidation on the VWT_2 catalyst in line with the catalytic studies (Section 3.2). It is assumed that the expected νas band of the carbonate moieties is overlapped by the broad feature at 1560 cm−1 [60]. After switching to the mixture of 50 ppm HCHO, 50 ppm NH3 and 7 % O2 a prominent formation of gaseous CO and CO2 is rapidly observed over a period of approx. 3 min (Fig. 12) referred to the oxidation of the formate species; the clear production of CO2 is referred to the absence of water during in-situ DRIFTS in contrast to the catalytic studies, which are carried out with 12 % H2O (Fig. 3). Accordingly, the prominent DRIFTS band of the formates at 1568 cm−1 promptly decreases and remains as a weak signal, whereas the formate bands between 2840 and 2970 cm−1 completely vanish after 20 min (Fig. 11). Additionally, the weak carbonate band at approx. 1340 cm−1 also remains and tends to increase slightly. Moreover, substantial bands at 1685 cm−1 (δs(NH2)) and around 1425 cm−1 (δas(NH2)) increasingly appears, which are interpreted with NH4 + species formed from the chemisorption of NH3 on Bronsted acid sites. Additionally, features at 1600 cm−1 (δas(NH2)) and 1265 cm−1 (δs(NH2)) also rise due to molecular adsorption of NH3 on Lewis acid sites [61]. The progressive NH3 adsorption is also discernible by the increasing concentration of NH3 in the outlet flow of the IR cell (Fig. 12). Considering the first DRIFT spectrum collected after 5 min, a band peaking at 1662 cm−1 is observed with shoulders at 1685 cm−1 (NH4 +) and 1638 cm−1. The 1662 and 1638 cm−1 features are increasingly superimposed by the strongly growing 1685 cm−1 signal and are therefore hardly resolved with further exposure time. The band located at 1638 cm−1 is attributed to δas(NH2) vibrations of NH3 molecularly coordinated to Lewis basic sites such as O2- ions [62], whereas the band at 1662 cm−1 is ascribed to the ν(CO) vibration of formamide [63]. The later band might be connected with the feature at 1370 cm−1, which is tentatively assigned to the δ(CH) vibration of the formamide. However, this rather weak band is shifted to 1377 cm−1 with exposure time, probably due to some formation of nitrates from slight NH3 oxidation. A very strong band at this wavenumber is observed during the exposure of the catalyst to NH3/N2 at 250°C (not shown). Moreover, a prominent negative band appears at 1383 cm−1 ascribed to the interaction of NH3 with sulfate, which is present in small quantities on the surface of the TiO2 component [20,64]. Formamide is discussed as key intermediate for the formation of HCN (HCONH2 → HCN + H2O) [14,15,20]. Indeed, the formation of formamide shown in the in-situ DRIFTS investigation is connected with the appearance of HCN as indicated by the gas phase analysis (Fig. 12). However, HCN-related adsorbates are not found by DRIFTS, probably due to their relatively low surface concentrations under the conditions established. By contrast, when adjusting a gas mixture with higher HCHO and NH3 fractions of 500 ppm each (7 % O2), a weak band appears at 2199 cm−1 (ν(CN)) attributed to cyanide surface species (Fig. S8), whereas a feature ascribable to molecular HCN, i.e. ν(CN) vibration at 2095 cm−1, is not observed [65]. As expected, in case of dosing labelled H13CHO the ν(CN) vibration band of surface cyanide is shifted to a lower wavenumber (2139 cm−1). It should be noticed that in the DRIFT spectra collected during the exposure to 500 ppm of HCHO and NH3 at 250 °C more intense and strongly overlapping bands appears, for instance νas(OCO) vibrations of surface formates at 1575 cm−1, making the identification of formamide-related bands difficult (Fig. S8). Since all the intense bands enveloped between 1400 and 1800 cm are shifted around 30–40 cm−1 to lower wavenumbers in the experiment with 500 H13CHO and NH3, it is obvious that the carbon containing surface species dominate over the ammonia adsorbates under these reaction conditions. Additionally, in contrast to the DRIFTS studies with 50 ppm HCHO, carbonate species markedly form as suggested by the clear features at 1270 and 1676 cm−1 [60]. There is a debate in the literature on the mechanism of the formamide production on VWT catalysts. On the one hand, it has been claimed that HCONH2 is formed by the reaction of NH3/NH4 + adsorbates with formates, which originate from the oxidation of HCHO on the catalyst [14,15]. On the other hand, the participation of surface formates has been explicitly excluded, but without suggesting an alternative pathway of the HCONH2 formation [20]. The present DRIFTS study suggests that the interaction of HCHO with the VWT_2 catalyst results in surface formates, which subsequently react with adsorbed NH3 and O2 to yield COx and HCONH2. Other carbon containing intermediates have not been identified. Therefore, it is supposed that formate species as well as NH3 adsorbates are most likely involved in the production of formamide. By contrast, the participation of molecular formic acid (HCOOH + NH3 → HCONH2 + H2O) potentially originating from the partial oxidation of HCHO (HCHO + 0.5 O2 → HCOOH) is rather excluded, as HCOOH has not been detected during the combined surface and gas phase analyses. 4 Conclusions The present study dealt with the simultaneous HCHO and SCR conversion in O2-rich model exhaust of gas engines using monolithic V2O5/WO3-TiO2 extrudates. The catalysts were industrially available and revealed V2O5 contents between 0 and 3 wt%. As a result, the catalysts with V2O5 loads of 2.0 and 3.0 wt% showed highest performance for the removal of HCHO and NOx. However, HCN was observed as by-product of the HCHO/SCR reaction. In the literature it has been controversially discussed whether the HCN production mechanism includes formamide as intermediate [17,22], originated from HCOOH and NH3, or methanolamine directly formed from HCHO and NH3 [16]. The in-situ DRIFTS investigations presented in this study rather suggest that formamide acts as the key intermediate including the participation of surface formates and NH3 adsorbates. Furthermore, the investigation of the axial HCN concentration profile inside the monolithic catalyst with a V2O5 load of 2.0 wt% evidenced a substantial decomposition of HCN at 250°C and above. This decay is associated with the hydrolysis (HCN + H2O → NH3 + CO) and oxidation of HCN (4 HCN + 5 O2 → 4 CO2 + 2 N2 +2H2O). As a consequence of these results, the HCN emission can be minimized in practice by increasing the length of the monolith and decreasing the GHSV, respectively. For 500°C, which is a typical exhaust temperature of stationary lean gas engines, it is estimated that HCN can be completely removed by adjusting a GHSV of approx. 9000 h−1. This estimation is based on the operation conditions used in the present study, i.e. 300 ppm NO, 315 ppm NH3, 100 ppm HCHO, 700 ppm CO, 1500 ppm CH4, 7 % O2, 12 % CO2 and 12 % H2O. Nevertheless, to minimize the HCN output of the VWT catalyst for the entire range of real operation conditions a kinetic model is required, which describes the complex reaction network of SCR, NH3 oxidation, HCHO oxidation as well as formation, hydrolysis and oxidation of HCN. Although the combined HCHO and SCR conversion is effective to decrease the output of NOx and HCHO, it should be highlighted that both the HCHO oxidation as well as the hydrolysis of HCN result in the formation of CO, which is hardly oxidized on VWT catalysts. Thus, the simultaneous HCHO/SCR reaction is suggested to be primarily useful for gas engines with a CO raw emission clearly below the legal limits. Moreover, the structure-activity-selectivity correlations indicated that highly dispersed VOx sites reveal highest efficiency for the HCHO oxidation preferentially producing CO and H2O. By contrast, oligomeric and polymeric two-dimensional vanadia species are less active. Additionally, the highly dispersed VOx sites also support the HCN formation. This might be explained by the enhanced HCHO oxidation leading to HCOOH or surface formats, which can subsequently react with NH3 to formamide finally decomposing to HCN and H2O. Furthermore, the present study showed that the high efficiency of the highly dispersed VOx entities during the HCHO conversion is over-compensated by the increased quantity of the less active aggregated VOx moieties, which are predominately present in the VWT catalysts with the higher V2O5 loads (2 and 3 wt%). However, the activity of VWT catalysts with respect to the combined HCHO/SCR conversion could be improved by using a surface-rich WO3/TiO2 support, on which a high proportion of very active VOx sites such as monomers and oligomers can exist. Such VOx sites are known to provide substantial HCHO oxidation and SCR efficiency. Nevertheless, regarding the SCR reaction these kinds of VOx sites are a compromise, since polymeric vanadia species have been shown to reveal higher specific performance compared to monomeric and oligomeric sites [66]. coredata.dc:description: Monolithic V2O5/WO3-TiO2 catalysts with vanadia loads between 0 and 3 wt% were investigated toward the simultaneous HCHO oxidation and SCR reaction in synthetic lean-burn CH4 engine exhaust. The catalysts were characterized by N2 physisorption, temperature programmed desorption of NH3, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, UV/Vis spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy coupled with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy. The catalytic studies showed increasing NOx and HCHO conversions with rising V2O5 content accompanied by side-production of HCN. At 250°C and above the HCN formation mainly occurred at the catalyst inlet followed by hydrolysis and oxidation of HCN along the monolith. Moreover, the correlation of the characteristics with the performance of the catalysts suggested that highly dispersed VOx sites are predominately involved in the HCHO oxidation and HCN formation, whereas aggregated two-dimensional VOx species are less active. Finally, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopic studies suggested that formamide acts as key intermediate of the HCN formation.
